question: Where are my clothes? A blob beneath the sheets next to him answers. SIMONE is the model on the walls and is really, really hot.
answer: In the kitchen. I think. Can I make you some coffee?

question: Sorry, I gotta go. I'm late. Richard hurries to the kitchen. Socks are on the butcher block next to an empty champagne bottle. Shoes in the sink. He finds his pants on the floor and puts them on. RICHARD Have you seen my belt? Simone looks around and sees it tied to her headboard.
answer: In here. She unties the complicated knot. Richard comes back half dressed. He swallows a little throwup.

question: Baby, I just can't do this anymore. You're just too much for me. And I'm just another guy too wrapped up in his job.
answer: Fine. Whatever. Just go. Richard sits down on the bed and locks eyes with Simone.

question: Let's not end it like that. It's been an amazing three and a half weeks. Thank you. And you should know that you have the nicest ass I've ever been with. I do. It's magnificent.
answer: I work really hard on it.

question: I know you do. Simone smiles and begins to seductively pull the sheets off her naked body. Richard shakes his head "no" and smiles. RICHARD I really gotta go.
answer: I knew you would call! Now come on, tell me what I want to hear. Give it to me. You should get paid extra for being so darn funny. Margaret straightens her jacket, answers the phone, and walks out the door. MARGARET This is Margaret.

question: Jillian, you are the best. See ya tomorrow. She doesn't exactly consult with me on these things. Welcome to my nightmare. The doors close as...
answer: You've been thinking about our talk because I'm right. Everyone does publicity. Roth, McCourt, Russo. Hell, Chabon practically whores himself. Know what they have in common? A Pulitzer. Yes, I know you haven't done it in twenty years, but that's how long it's been since you've written a book this good. I'm not pushing so you'll sell more books, I'm pushing because it'll be a crime if the world doesn't hear that you wrote a genius piece of literature. Do the publicity. Margaret waits for an answer and smiles when she hears "yes." MARGARET You're making the right decision! Great news. Going into an elevator, think I'm going to lose you... Margaret hangs up. Never give them a chance to change their mind.

question: You've got a conference call in thirty, a staff meeting at nine, and your immigration lawyer sent some papers for you to sign.
answer: Cancel the call, move the meeting to eight,

question: Nice job.
answer: When I want your praise, I'll ask for it. Is Bob here?

question: I'm sure. You want him on the phone?
answer: We're going to his office. Grab your pad. Richard calmly backs out of the office... That's cute. You gonna call her today?

question: What? Richard doesn't know what Margaret is talking about, until she nods at the cup. He's embarrassed.
answer: Are you bored here? Do you need little distractions like that to get you through the day?

question: Uh...
answer: You have another late night out? I'm firing on all cylinders and you've got hearts on your coffee cup, wicked bed head, and a wrinkled suit that you wore yesterday.

question: Oh. Well, it won't be wrinkled for long.
answer: You'll magically unwrinkle?

question: Yes.
answer: You have magic pants?

question: No. I've sprayed them with stuff that will take care of the wrinkles.
answer: Does this work on more than just your pants?

question: Anything that's wrinkled.
answer: Buy me some.

question: Will do. Richard makes a note. Margaret stops to make her point.
answer: I don't care what or who you do on your own time, but when you walk through that door you represent me, and I will not have your personal life affect you at work. If you want me to think of promoting you to editor, I need you sharp, focused and professional. Got it?

question: Got it.
answer: Great. Now you're just a prop in here, so don't say a word. Hey, Bob.

question: Great. Now you're just a prop in here, so don't say a word. Hey, Bob.
answer: Ah. Our fearless leader and her liege. Margaret smiles.

question: I'm lettin' you go, Bob.
answer: Pardon?

question: You're fired.
answer: What? What are you talking about?

question: This isn't working out.
answer: You can't...

question: I asked you repeatedly to get Frank to do publicity. You said it was impossible.
answer: It is. He doesn't do publicity.

question: I just talked to him. He's in.
answer: But...

question: Oh Bob, don't do it...
answer: YOU POISONOUS BITCH! YOU CAN'T FIRE ME! The office stops. This is going to be good. Margaret turns around with a disappointed look on her face. She's deadly calm.

question: What are you doing? I gave you a civilized way out of this.
answer: This is because I'm your competition. Because I threaten you!

question: Oh, Bob. You could never threaten me. I'm firing you because you're lazy, entitled and incompetent. I'm firing you because you don't work hard. So if you know what's good for you, you'll shut up, take off that ridiculous bow tie, find a bar and get drunk. Because if you say one more word, Richard here is going to call security and have you thrown out on your ass. Are we perfectly clear? Bob nods. MARGARET Good. Now I've got work to do, so if you'll
answer: No problem. I'll just cancel my trip this weekend.

question: I gave you the weekend off?
answer: It was my Grandma's ninetieth birthday. But no big deal. You were right before, I need to stay focused. Professional. Well tell gammy that I'm sorry. Mom, she's making me work this weekend. It's not like I volunteered. I'm sure dad is pissed. Margaret comes to Richard's desk. He tries to wrap it up. RICHARD I have to go. Yeah. No, I'm not going to do that! No. Sorta. Mom! No. Bye. Richard hangs up the phone. RICHARD Sorry about that. Damage control.

question: She tell you to quit?
answer: No. No. Um. Yes? But as I've explained to them, after three years together, you're the only person on the planet who can make me editor, so that's the way it is. Richard's phone rings and he picks it up.

question: Who is this guy?
answer: He said you knew each other. You weren't sure so you told me to set a meeting. We rescheduled on him four times.

question: Go get him. But he's out of here in five minutes, we've got work to do. Margaret leaves and goes into her office.
answer: I'll charge up the cattle prod.

question: Margaret. Good to see you. I know how busy you are. Congrats on the promotion. Read about it in P-W.
answer: Yeah. Well, those announcements are silly, aren't they? Like everyone who needs to know doesn't know already. Margaret has been trying to figure out how she knows this man, but now gives up. MARGARET Have to admit, I can't place where we know each other from. Gilbertson smiles. He didn't expect her to remember.

question: Three years ago? We worked together.
answer: Don't have it...

question: Remember "Dandelion's Desire?" Margaret gets excited.
answer: Oh my God, you read that manuscript with me? That book is legend. Without a doubt the worst ever written.

question: You think?
answer: It was a fever dream! 900 offensive and pointless pages, with like 30 characters, who all had some weird disability. The paraplegic pornographer, and the stuttering scientist? Oh! And there was the asthmatic alien chapter -- written entirely in his alien language.

question: I believe there was a glossary... Margaret laughs, caught up in the memory.
answer: Did you see the pass letter I wrote him? You wrote the book.

question: I did.
answer: You're Dante Dickens?

question: One of my nom de plumes. Gilbertson paces. Margaret stays seated, at a loss.
answer: I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings. You obviously were spending a lot of time writing, I just thought you should channel all that passion into something else. Gilbertson smiles as he pulls a BADGE from his coat pocket.

question: Ms. Mills, I'm with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, and I'm deporting you to Canada.
answer: Excuse me? What? This is a mistake. I've lived here since 1981. I'm applying for citizenship.

question: You need citizenship now? After the big promotion?
answer: Yes. And all the papers are in. Gilbertson pulls out a stack of papers and throws them down.

question: Well, my office is going to reject your paperwork on Monday, while we investigate whether your behavior is well disposed to the good order and happiness of the United States. We must protect our sovereignty.
answer: I'm a threat to the sovereignty of the United States?

question: Yes, and unfortunately my investigation will take awhile, so you'll be deported while your case winds through the system. Will it affect you at work if you aren't allowed to enter the U.S. for the next two to three years?
answer: "Affect me at work?" I'll lose my job!

question: Ahhhh. That's a shame. Too bad we can't work something out. Margaret stops looking at her file. It all becomes clear.
answer: Oh, no. No, no, no. I won't do it.

question: Do what, Ms. Mills? I've edited it down. It's better.
answer: Well then, get it published at another house.

question: They all just don't get me.
answer: All?

question: Well not all. Two hundred fifty, two hundred sixty-one. Ish.
answer: I'll be fired and laughed out of the industry if I publish that book.

question: I'm at the end of my rope, Ms. Mills. I'm an author. Not some bureaucrat who brings a lunchable to work everyday and lives in his brother's garage. You're the last stop, and I'm desperate.
answer: I will never publish your book. Ever.

question: There's no need to make this difficult. I don't turn in your file until Monday...
answer: This is blackmail. I'll go to your boss.

question: Excuse me, Ms. Mills, risk management needs you right away. The sight of Richard inspires Margaret. She turns to Gilbertson with a wicked grin on her face.
answer: Know what, Dante? I'm not going anywhere! We're getting married! Richard has no idea what Margaret is talking about.

question: Who's getting married?
answer: We are!

question: You and him?
answer: Stop playing around, honey. Margaret is all smiles. Richard is very confused. MARGARET Mr. Gilbertson is from the INS. I told him about us. About us getting married.

question: You are marrying your male assistant?
answer: We're in love. We tried to fight it. When it's right, it's right.

question: And this has nothing to do with my visit here today?
answer: Nope. True love. Got it bad.

question: You. Is this true? Are you marrying this... woman? Margaret comes over to Richard and holds his hand.
answer: Of course we are.

question: Plum.
answer: You mean purple?

question: No. Plum is "smokier" than purple.
answer: Favorite flower?

question: Tulips. But only when they're in season.
answer: Childhood pet name?

question: Yes. We are. We're surprising them... ...at his Grandma's 90th birthday party.
answer: And where's that going to be?

question: At Richard's parent's house.
answer: And where's that located?

question: There are no "T's" or "I's" in "Love" Mr. Gilbertson. Gilbertson leaves and shuts the door hard. Margaret goes back to her desk like this is all in a days work. MARGARET Why are you from Alaska? Sweet Jesus, that's inconvenient. So here's what's going to happen. We'll play boyfriend and girlfriend this weekend for your parents and that should be enough for this INS interview. Richard doesn't react. Margaret doesn't notice. MARGARET So you need to figure out the travel, schedule a justice of the peace for next week, and get my lawyer on the phone. Margaret takes a sip of her coffee and makes a face. MARGARET But first, run down and get me another coffee from your girlfriend, this is cold. Margaret holds out her coffee cup. Richard doesn't move. MARGARET Hello? Richard? Richard! Richard says his first words since Gilbertson left.
answer: I quit. Richard leaves Margaret's office. She still has her coffee cup outstretched in her hand.

question: Richard, come back here. Margaret tries not to make a scene. MARGARET Richard. Richard. Richard pushes the elevator button in front of reception. MARGARET Come back to the office! Richard can't take it. He gets up in Margaret's face.
answer: You shut up. You just lost your "I get to tell Richard what to do" privileges.

question: Well, we need to talk.
answer: You want to talk with me? Fine. Grab your broom and let's go. Margaret is dumbstruck. The receptionist is shocked. The elevator arrives and Richard gets in. Margaret follows. As the doors close, Richard shouts out to the receptionist. RICHARD Watch my phones! Your plan is psychotic.

question: Well I'd rather poke my eyes out than play pretend girlfriend, but this is the big time. Sometimes you need to sack up.
answer: Aren't Canadians supposed to be nice?

question: You wanna be an editor? You need to make
answer: OK. Fine. Then if we "make this happen"? You're promoting me to editor.

question: I'm doing what?
answer: We go to Alaska and lie to my family? I risk going to jail? Well, you're making me editor for that. I mean, did you think I'd do this out of the kindness of my heart?

question: You work for me!
answer: You know, during my employee orientation, the HR rep didn't mention anything about me marrying you.

question: Look, I came to this town alone and with nothing. I've worked my ass off for fifteen years and this guy wants to ruin me because he wrote the shittiest book of all time? No way.
answer: Nice story Little Orphan Annie, but that sounds like your problem. Not mine. Margaret is stuck. Richard really does have the upper hand.

question: Fine. You take me to Alaska this weekend, and I'll make you editor. Deal? Margaret puts out her hand to shake, Richard takes it. MARGARET And I'm not sleeping on your parent's hide-a- bed, we're staying in a hotel. Do they even have hotels in Alaska?
answer: No. But they have huts. Teepees really. And you have to poop in a bucket. But otherwise, just like the Four Seasons. But with bears. Um. Shouldn't we talk about what we're going to say to my parents? Margaret doesn't look up, annoyed with the question.

question: Are you done with the press release?
answer: Almost.

question: So what do I need to know up there? Bullet points.
answer: I told em we've been dating for six months. We've kept it a secret from everyone... ...and that you're a naughty minx in the sack. Richard and Margaret make it to the attendant at the gate. Margaret is not amused by Richard's attempt at humor. Bringing her home to meet my folks. She's OK then. You're a sweet lady. Thanks. Richard hustles to the plane as they shut the doors.

question: I'm sorry, I hate it when people stare at what I'm reading. It's just... I worked on that book.
answer: You wrote it?

question: Edited it. It was one of my favorites.
answer: Well you did a good job. It's great.

question: You don't see many guys with that book. You, uh, read a lot of love stories about Roman concubines?
answer: My ex-girlfriend gave it to me. I travel a lot for work. I'll read anything... OK, you got me. I'm a closet romantic. But let's keep that between us. Margaret smiles and makes the "my lips are sealed" motion. Just then, Richard lumbers onto the plane with the bags.

question: I know, Richard. Richard turns around and puts the bags in the overhead compartment. The Handsome Man turns to Margaret.
answer: Did you two want to sit together?

question: Sit together with who? The Handsome man nods at Richard.
answer: Your boyfriend? Margaret points to Richard indignantly.

question: You mean him? The Handsome man nods. Margaret tries to set the record straight. MARGARET No. No. No. He's my assistant.
answer: You're bringing your assistant all the way to Alaska? Richard smiles, happy that Margaret has to answer.

question: Now, ah, where did you hear that? The whole "getting married" thing?
answer: Oh, that man from the government. Gilber- something. Said he was checking up on you two. Said it was technicality, because Margaret was from Canada.

question: What, ah, did you tell him?
answer: Well for one thing, that you were in a lot of trouble for not telling us that you two were getting married!

question: No. Really. What did you say?
answer: Just that you were coming up here this weekend. That we hadn't seen you in a while, and that we'd heard about Margaret for years, but that we'd never met her. Debbie turns to Margaret and takes both of her hands. DEBBIE The way that Richard talked about you? I'll admit, I didn't see this coming.

question: So why all the silly secrecy?
answer: It wasn't a secret. We didn't tell anyone.

question: Well, is your family just anyone?
answer: No, I didn't mean...

question: When Gilber-something told us you were getting married... ...God rest their souls...
answer: ...or friends...

question: ...we decided to give you a wedding.
answer: Engagement party tonight...

question: Either way.
answer: Hey dad. Richard shakes his father's hand. It's a little stiff.

question: Welcome home. Good to see ya.
answer: You too.

question: Been a while.
answer: Yeah. You'd think you could make it to the airport to mark the occasion. Grandma Annie interrupts.

question: We'll show you around later.
answer: Uh huh.

question: Balzac! Down! No! Debbie pulls the dog off of Margaret and pushes him toward the kitchen. Margaret tries to take it in stride and make small talk.
answer: What a great name. Balzac's "Lost Illusions" is one of my favorite novels.

question: You'll be sleeping here. Bathroom is there, all the towels are in the armoire by the bed. Just let me know if you
answer: Thank you. Where's Richard's room?

question: Oh, we took down his "shrine" years ago. And don't worry, I'm under no illusion that you two haven't slept in the same bed before. Richard can sleep here too.
answer: Oh, let's not upset Grandma Annie.

question: It was her idea. Anything to help get her a great grandchild. Richard shrugs his shoulders behind his mother.
answer: Great. You know, I've gotten used to his breathing at night.

question: I thought so dear. Debbie leaves and shuts the door. Margaret reverts back to her old self.
answer: I'm about 15 seconds from bitch.

question: I'm about 15 seconds from bitch.
answer: Calm down.

question: What is going on here?
answer: Hell if I know.

question: You had no idea they knew about us getting married?
answer: You think I'd bring you here if I did?

question: Well, we just gotta tell em.
answer: Tell em what?

question: Tell em the truth. About us.
answer: Wrong answer. No way.

question: What do you mean no way? This is crazy.
answer: No, crazy was lying to the federal officer.

question: Well I don't like this.
answer: Well I'm not making my Gammy an accomplice to a Class C felony! For one second could you not be so selfish?

question: Selfish?
answer: Yeah, you know, that thing you do where you only worry about yourself every second of every day?

question: How is it selfish to tell the truth?
answer: Look. We're awful, awful people. In the last forty eight hours, we've lied to... everyone. We need to protect the people downstairs. We can't ask these good, decent, not awful people to lie for us. Let's keep the darkside to ourselves. Margaret takes a second to make up her mind.

question: Fine. But if we do this, you need to stop lying to me.
answer: What've I lied to you about?

question: Why did you tell me that you were poor?
answer: I never said that.

question: Well, you never told me you were rich.
answer: When does that come up?

question: I don't know, how about, "Hi, my name is Richard, I'm an Alaskan titan of industry."
answer: Well, maybe I didn't tell you because you would have fired me if you knew.

question: No I wouldn't.
answer: Come on! You're always yammering on about your scrappy childhood, and how you fought for those soccer scholarships, and how the rich kids made fun of you in prep school for working in the kitchen. You're totally anti- rich.

question: I'm not anti-rich.
answer: Oh yes you are! And you know what makes it worse? You have money!

question: I earned...
answer: ...every penny I have. Blah, blah, blah. You need new material.

question: Hey. Watch it. You're still my assistant.
answer: You were going to promote me anyway.

question: Sure of that?
answer: Nope. Not at all. Margaret takes a look at herself in the mirror.

question: Well, come on. If we're going to do this, we might as well put on a show. I went to Union college in upstate New York. It's a small liberal arts school that no one has ever heard of. Richard comes to the group and hands Margaret a drink. MARGARET Lime?
answer: Be right back. Richard leaves to fetch lime wedges. Geoffrey elbows Debbie in the side, "What was that?"

question: Since I graduated college. Richard comes back with the lime. Margaret takes it and doesn't say thank you.
answer: She's been there since she was nineteen.

question: Nineteen? Wow. That's how long?
answer: Oh, who's counting... Geoffrey could let it go, but wants to push her.

question: No. How many years is that? Exactly. Margaret gives Geoffrey the slightest look.
answer: Well, let me see. That would be sixteen or seventeen years. Exactly.

question: I was never good with big numbers. That makes you... thirty six now?
answer: Just turned thirty seven. Born on May 20th. I'm a Taurus. Geoffrey and Margaret give each other a smile. MARGARET I need some protein.

question: Gert!? Richard snaps his arm back, hitting Margaret in the head, and spilling her tonic water on her shirt. He doesn't notice what he's done, and leaves Margaret. She's peeved. RICHARD
answer: Your dad made me come.

question: From Chicago? Gertrude laughs. The group watches these two see each for the first time in years. There is instant chemistry, and Richard has forgotten about Margaret completely.
answer: No. I live here now.

question: You what?
answer: I moved back about six months ago. I'm teaching second grade. At Baranof.

question: Did your husband move up here too?
answer: Uh, no. I, ah, got divorced.

question: Oh my God. I'm sorry.
answer: Me too. But hey, we're being rude, I wanna meet the bride. Gertrude leaves Richard and goes to Margaret.

question: Where's Margaret? We need to go.
answer: Go where?

question: It's a surprise. Girls are going into town. And the boys stay here. I told you, we've planned everything.
answer: Um. She's outside. Debbie and Richard turn around and look out a picture window. They see Margaret running with Balzac above her head.

question: This is a delicious dog, Mr. Eagle. C'mon, bring back the phone. Richard calls out from the house.
answer: What are you doing?

question: The eagle took my phone!
answer: Are you drunk?

question: Your dad was right! The eagle tried to take the dog, so I saved it, then it came back and took my phone.
answer: Did the dingo eat your baby, too?

question: Frank's going to call me on that phone. I need it!
answer: Relax. I've got your information backed up on the laptop. I'll just get you a new phone and switch the number. No problem.

question: Oh.
answer: Now come on. You're going somewhere with my mom and the girls.

question: I'm not going anywhere.
answer: You want a new phone? You're going.

question: Why's that, Mr. Maguire?
answer: You fly up here and don't call me?

question: Sorry bout that.
answer: What good is me owning an airline if I can't give you free tickets?

question: You're right. Don't know what I was thinking...
answer: Damn, straight. Don't let it happen again! Here, you take over. This game is for pussies, I'm getting a drink. Mr. Maguire leaves, and Richard and Geoffrey are left alone with one another for the first time. Things are awkward between father and son, and Richard begins hitting balls to avoid conversation. Geoffrey finally makes small talk.

question: Maguire's stepping down in January. He's, uh, handing things over to Matty. Richard gives his dad a look. He knows where this is going.
answer: That's great for them.

question: So. How's work with you?
answer: Good. Busy. You know.

question: I do. I do. Hey, did I tell you that we're opening a little office in Japan?
answer: Congratulations.

question: We're not just a mom and pop operation anymore. We're going global.
answer: Uh-huh. Geoffrey stops hitting golf balls for a second. He's been thinking about this moment for a long time.

question: I could really use your help.
answer: Dad. Please. I'm in New York. Margaret's in New York. We have jobs.

question: I know. I know. It's just... You're only a secretary. This pisses Richard off immediately.
answer: Again with the secretary thing! I've told you, I'm an assistant!

question: Just because you call yourself an "assistant" doesn't mean you're not really just a secretary.
answer: Well if I'm "just a secretary", why would you want me up here anyway? Sounds like you're doing great without me.

question: It's not like that and you know it.
answer: Then how is it? Explain it to me. Geoffrey looks around to see if anyone is listening.

question: Last week, a man stuck his finger up my butt...
answer: This man was a doctor?

question: ...and it got me thinking about you.
answer: I'm not sure this is coming out right.

question: Just shut up for a second, okay? I want you to have what I built. But I'm running out of time to show you things.
answer: Stop being so dramatic.

question: I'm not being... I need you to stop dicking around down there and get serious.
answer: So this is all about what you want?

question: That's not what I said.
answer: And me in New York with Margaret? That isn't serious?

question: One day the woman is the Antichrist, and the next day she's the love of your life? How is that serious?
answer: Things change, dad. Things change.

question: Things change?
answer: Yes. Things change.

question: Things change. That's your explanation? Know what I think? I think you banged your boss and fell in love, that's what I think. Some sorta mommy complex.
answer: Nice, dad. We gotta have these Cosby moments more often. This is great. Richard drops his club and walks back to the house.

question: They can be a little overwhelming, but they're great people.
answer: What? I'm just working on my tan. It's been a long day. Margaret looks inside and sees that the party is still raging.

question: Around the solstice they don't watch the clock. Pretty much party til they fall over. I actually missed it when I was in the states.
answer: Chicago, right?

question: Yeah. Since college.
answer: And now you're back?

question: Six months now. Call me crazy, but I love it. Think I'm back for good.
answer: Really? I don't know. Don't you miss...

question: Neimans? Starbucks? Escalators? Margaret laughs. She likes this woman. GERTRUDE Yeah. I miss it. Believe me, growing up I never thought I'd end up divorced and back here teaching at my old elementary school. That was always Richard's plan.
answer: For you to get divorced?

question: No. I was going to teach, he was going to run his dad's business. He was like a little old man. Had it all worked out.
answer: Are we talking about the same guy?

question: What do you mean?
answer: Well, Richard's such a player. Gertrude looks confused. MARGARET I mean he was a total player. Before we started dating. Six months ago. That surprises you?

question: Did he ever tell you why we broke up?
answer: We don't really talk much about stuff like that.

question: Oh. Well I should shut up...
answer: No, no. Please. I mean, we are getting married. I want to know these things. Gertrude looks down a little embarrassed.

question: He proposed to me. When we were seniors. Margaret laughs.
answer: I'm sorry. I didn't mean to... He proposed to you in high school?

question: He bought this sweet little ring, and got down on his knee. It was so cute.
answer: You must have...

question: ... freaked out? Oh you bet. I broke up with him on the spot.
answer: I would hope so.

question: After getting rejected the first time, I can't imagine how hard it was for him to get up the courage to ask you. Margaret just smiles, feeling guilty about lying when Gertrude is being so honest with her. GERTRUDE Anyway. The idea that my little old man could be a player... It's just not the Richard I knew. Good thing you're making an honest man of him again.
answer: I'll be right in. Margaret smiles and turns to the ocean. Gertrude goes inside. Then, to herself, Margaret silently whispers. MARGARET We are awful people.

question: Margaret turns off the shower, pulls back the curtain and reaches for a towel. All she finds is a miniature unabsorbent decorative hand towel. Shit. Margaret's ears perk up. The bathroom is a disaster because she has dripped water everywhere looking for a towel.
answer: Richard, is that you?

question: Margaret cracks the door open to see what the sound was. Richard isn't there, but she sees the armoire open and the towels waiting for her. How did she miss that?
answer: Richard, are you... Then out of nowhere, Balzac startles Margaret.

question: Naked, wet, and starting to get a little pissed off, Margaret manages to pull herself up by the toilet. She wants a towel badly, but Balzac guards the doorway. She tries reason.
answer: I'm sorry bout the eagle. But I saved you. Balzac won't listen to reason and barks angrily. Margaret grabs the ceramic top of the toilet tank to protect herself.

question: Will you just hand me a towel! Richard looks for a towel, but forgets he's naked. When he looks under the bed, Margaret shrieks and covers her eyes.. MARGARET You're flashing brain! Richard quickly changes positions. Out of desperation, he pulls the entire comforter off the bed. He throws it Margaret's way, and she wraps herself in it.
answer: I didn't know you were home! I was outside chopping wood!

question: You didn't hear me?
answer: I had my iPod on!

question: I didn't jump you. I didn't mean to jump you. I didn't know you were here.
answer: You didn't see me?

question: I was running from the dog! Richard looks at Margaret suspiciously.
answer: Wait. Were you tryin' to seduce me?

question: Oh please! Don't flatter yourself.
answer: Mmm-Hmmm.

question: Go take a shower. You stink.
answer: Fine. But don't come sneaking in there. You're still my boss. That'd be sexual harassment.

question: I'm never gonna to get to sleep. Richard pushes a button and motorized metal blinds come down outside the window. The sunlight is instantly blocked out and the room is pitch black. MARGARET Oh. Well. Thanks. Richard settles into his pathetic excuse for a bed. The two silently lie awake and stare at the dark ceiling.
answer: It was kinda weird seeing you naked.

question: Can we not talk about this?
answer: I'm just saying. It was weird.

question: It wasn't weird.
answer: How was that not weird?

question: Because we're... like teammates.
answer: We're like teammates?

question: We are teammates. And teammates see each other naked in the locker room. All the time. It's not a big deal.
answer: Well, if we're teammates can I sleep in the bed?

question: Good night, Richard. The two lay awake in silence for another beat.
answer: Margaret?

question: Yes?
answer: Don't take this the wrong way.

question: Okay...
answer: You're a very beautiful woman. Margaret smiles with her head turned away from Richard.

question: It's me dear. I made you two breakfast in bed. Can I come in?
answer: What the... Come on in mom! Debbie enters with a tray of pastries, fruit and coffee. RICHARD Ah mom, you made your cinnamon rolls.

question: Well, it's your special day. Debbie smiles, puts down the tray on a bedside table and sits on the edge of the bed. She is buzzing with excitement. DEBBIE You two need your energy, so eat up. We've got your dress fitting, have to get the house ready, and then your wedding.
answer: I gotta run into town to get Margaret a new phone.

question: Will you pick up some champagne while you're there?
answer: No problem.

question: I wish she hadn't. I mean she almost caught us. Damn, that was close. Like a pig in shit, Richard continues to dig in and doesn't pay attention to Margaret.
answer: You just take all this for granted? Your family, this house... Richard takes another big bite and turns to Margaret.

question: I'm sorry, what? You gotta try these. Margaret looks at Richard with disgust.
answer: Why are you doing this to them?

question: Huh?
answer: Why am I here? You didn't have to bring me here.

question: You made me bring you here! You told me I
answer: I didn't make you do anything. You could of said no.

question: And what? Start over at the bottom again? No way.
answer: I get why a not rich person would do this. But you've got everything. It doesn't make any sense.

question: Know what? This is none of your business.
answer: I wish it wasn't my business. But unfortunately, it has become my business, because I made a deal with someone I thought I could trust. Richard stares at Margaret for a beat. He's exasperated.

question: You wanna know why you're here? I'll show you why you're here.
answer: Fine.

question: We leave in a half hour.
answer: I'll be ready in 20 minutes. Margaret angrily takes a bite of a cinnamon roll and slams it down on the plate. She goes to her suitcase and looks for clothes. A beat passes, and she comes back to the rolls. MARGARET These are really good. She takes a cinnamon roll and leaves.

question: Yes sir, it is!
answer: That's great to hear.

question: See ya on the line, Bek Bek. Put this on. I'll meet you outside.
answer: But I don't...

question: Ah. Put it on.
answer: Is this really necessary?

question: You'll thank me later. Richard walks towards the warehouse. Margaret follows in her
answer: Why is he handcuffed to the machine?

question: So his hands don't go too far. So he doesn't... Richard makes a chopping motion. Margaret winces.
answer: Nice. From the decapitator, fish are fed into the gut puller, where their bellies are slit and the intestines are pulled out. MARGARET You know, I shouldn't be here. I was a vegetarian for six months in college. Richard leads Margaret to the end of slime line, where a long line of 20 workers give the fish a final cleaning before they are frozen. With great speed, they take the fish from the gut puller line and clean out all the left over intestines.

question: Ah, it's been a while. Okay, okay. Richard and Margaret go to the end of the line. Richard expertly demonstrates with a knife. RICHARD You grab a fish, but be gentle, cause you don't want to bruise it. Open her up, tilt the knife, and then pull with the grain of the fish. Two quick stokes to clear the organs attached to the spine.
answer: Gimme that. Up to the challenge, she takes the knife and grabs a fish. Margaret puts the knife in and keeps as much distance as possible between her and the salmon.

question: I did this for five summers. Dad wanted me to earn my stripes before I took over.
answer: Is that why you're still pissed at him?

question: Nah, I loved it here.
answer: You loved this?

question: The slime line? Hell no. Nobody loves the slime line. I loved this place. The people. Growing up, running this place was all I wanted. Margaret scrapes a huge glop of guts out of a fish. I wanted to run this place. It was comfortable here. It was what I knew. Don't forget the spine.
answer: I wasn't gonna forget. Margaret squeezes the blood out of the vein, sends the fish on its way, and grabs another fish with more confidence.

question: But then things changed. And it wasn't so comfortable anymore.
answer: What kind of things changed?

question: Stuff.
answer: You mean, like, Gertrude?

question: Yeah... Richard stops, he can tell Margaret knows something. RICHARD Oh my god. She told you didn't she? About the... you know.
answer: The creepy teenage proposal?

question: Ah, shit!
answer: You were a freak by the way.

question: OK, get it all out.
answer: And she was right to break up with you.

question: You done? Margaret nods yes.
answer: For a little while? Don't sell yourself short.

question: When Gert crushed my heart into little pieces, a life up here didn't seem so great anymore.
answer: So you moved to the open arms of New York City?

question: At first it was about getting as far away from this place as possible, but then I fell in love with it.
answer: With scheduling my pilates?

question: With editing. See, as an only kid I'd always read a lot, but until I worked for you I didn't love it. I mean, when I realized that we could find the next Cuckoo's Nest, or Catch 22, or...
answer: ...To Kill a Mockingbird. It's all about To Kill a Mockingbird.

question: Exactly! We could find the next To Kill a Mockingbird. God damn, how great is that? Margaret smiles. She never knew that Richard had this kind of passion for the job. RICHARD So when I tell my folks that I want to spend my life finding books? My dad goes ape shit. "How dare you forsake your family... you'll come crawling back to us... you're nothing without our help." I left that night and we didn't talk for a year. Haven't been back here since.
answer: So we're "getting married" so you can give daddy the finger?

question: No. Margaret gives Richard a disbelieving look. RICHARD Sorta. OK, Yes. Coming back here with you... I get the promotion and I get to show off. You're editor in chief. You make a good prop. So now you know I'm a petty asshole. Am I trustworthy again?
answer: Oh yeah, we're good. By the way, you're more screwed up than I am, Paxton.

question: Yeah. Thanks.
answer: One more question...

question: Yes, everyone at work thinks you're a lesbian.
answer: That wasn't my question.

question: I know. Just lashing out. Margaret smiles.
answer: Can we stop gutting fish? I need my phone.

question: He was my shop teacher.
answer: Of course he was. How many people are on this island? They start to fill their cart with cases of champagne.

question: Like eight thousand? Depends on the time of the year.
answer: Feels smaller. With the cart full they head to the checkout.

question: Why's Ramone letting you steal his stuff?
answer: It's our stuff.

question: That must have been handy in High School.
answer: You have no idea.

question: Should you leave the cart?
answer: It's our cart. I didn't know you were such a prude.

question: I've come to realize that being my assistant gave you more access to my life than I ever imagined, but there are a few things you don't know about me.
answer: I doubt it. When I started, you were still wearing those Ugg boot things.

question: I told you never to talk about that.
answer: I'm just saying it's been a long time. I know it all. Margaret turns on her new phone. It searches for a signal.

question: Did you know I took disco lessons in the sixth grade?
answer: Where?

question: The Y.
answer: Margaret 1, Richard 0.

question: Uh, my first concert was Kool and the Gang.
answer: At Woodstock?

question: I won tickets on the radio and saw them at the fair.
answer: What'd they sing again?

question: You know.
answer: You had a lot of soul there, Canada.

question: I really like "The O.C.". Not fake, ha, ha isn't it funny I like this trash. I really like it.
answer: Wow. I'm getting shut out here.

question: Allergic to pine nuts.
answer: Knew that.

question: Afraid of penguins.
answer: Huh.

question: Haven't slept with a man in a year and a half.
answer: Holy shit! You are a lesbian! A MOTHER walking by with her 7 year old gives Richard a nasty look. RICHARD My bad. The mother walks on. Margaret is mortified and walks faster.

question: Kool and the Gang gets nothing, but that gets a Holy shit? I've been busy!
answer: That's a really long time.

question: That hurts coming from Mr. Magic Pants.
answer: I knew it had been slow going, but I figured there was a booty call in there somewhere.

question: Yeah, well, I'm not good at that.
answer: I find that hard to believe.

question: No, not that. I'm great at that. Aces. Top notch.
answer: I'll have to take your word for it.

question: Yes. You will.
answer: How, exactly, do you define top notch? Margaret is smiling as she listens to a message on her phone. In an instant, she's all business.

question: I need a computer and the internet. Now. No, no, no. I need on now. I've got a Booker prize winning author demanding I send him an e-mail in the next forty five minutes explaining why he should stay with a publishing house that "makes" him do publicity. The Pirate looks at Margaret like she's speaking Chinese. Listen to me asshole... The Pirate looks around to make sure his boss can't hear.
answer: C'mon. I got an idea. Richard leads Margaret to the door. As they are leaving Margaret shouts out.

question: Oh. Sure.
answer: Show me around will you Mrs. Whiting? It's been years.

question: Do you think she'll be long? I've got work to do.
answer: She'll be out of there in two shakes. Out of the corner of his eye, Richard catches Gertrude teaching a class of second graders. He stops transfixed.

question: We are so lucky to have her. Mr. Megher really left us shorthanded when he ran off in the middle of the school year. He's living out in the forest now with his wolves. Full time. Richard hasn't heard anything that Mrs. Whiting has said. He's hypnotized by Gertrude. She looks happy teaching these kids, and they hang on her every word. MRS. WHITING Will you excuse me? The bell is about to ring, I need to get ready for recess.
answer: Uh, sure. Mrs. Whiting leaves. Richard goes to the door and Gertrude sees him. Good lord can that woman smile. She waves him in.

question: Uh, sure. Mrs. Whiting leaves. Richard goes to the door and Gertrude sees him. Good lord can that woman smile. She waves him in.
answer: Class, this is my old friend Richard. Richard and I used to be in this very same classroom together. We even had your old teacher, Mr. Megher. That's not a nice thing to say, Patrick. The BELL RINGS. One girl gets up. Gertrude eyeballs her. GERTRUDE Marcia? OK, everyone is excused for recess. All the kids pop up and head to the door. Mrs. Whiting directs traffic outside. Richard makes his way to Gertrude.

question: Patrick's right. He did smell like eggs.
answer: It's still not a nice thing to say. And actually, Mr. Megher smelled like wet dog and... ...Matanuska Thunderfuck. But let's keep that between us.

question: Remember when Mr. Megher made us do this after school for a week?
answer: That was your fault.

question: Was not!
answer: You tried to kiss me. A girl has to defend herself.

question: C'mon! I had the shot. I took it. Gertrude rolls her eyes. She's heard this a hundred times.
answer: No Top Gun. Please.

question: What? You loved my Top Gun.
answer: No. You loved your Top Gun. I just smiled and laughed like a good girlfriend.

question: That's right. Ice... man. I am dangerous. Richard clicks his teeth together, trying to mimic Tom Cruise. Gertrude is not impressed. That cuts deep. I'll have you know that
answer: No. Nothing's wrong.

question: It's been awhile, but I can still tell when something's wrong with you. Gertrude doesn't want to say anything. RICHARD What is it? You know I hate it when you get all quiet.
answer: I wish there was a better way to say this.

question: Better way to say what?
answer: I made a huge mistake. With you. Breaking up with you. I'm sorry.

question: Are you apologizing for high school?
answer: Yes.

question: Oh, thank God. I thought this was like, something big.
answer: This is something big.

question: I coulda used this about five years ago, but I'm all good now, promise. Thank you for saying that, though. Gertrude sees that Richard isn't getting her point. She pulls herself together.
answer: I think... I want you back. Oh God, he's making me say it again. I want you back. Like... we should be together. All the time.

question: Whoa, whoa, whoa. Rewind.
answer: I know this isn't the best time to bring this up. I'm not talking about dating! You should move back here. We can have the life you always talked about in High School. I'm ready for that now.

question: Why are you doing this?
answer: I know that the timing here sucks. But we are meant to be together. I know it. I think you know it too...

question: Uh, you all done?
answer: Yeah. We'll see what he says.

question: Great. Great.
answer: You ready to get back to the house?

question: Uh. Yeah. Uh-huh.
answer: Well let's go. See you at the wedding, Gertrude. Gertrude just smiles.

question: So, what did you and Gertrude talk about? Richard lies.
answer: Nothing. About her school. The kids and stuff. Apparently my second grade teacher was a pot head.

question: That was it? I was gone for awhile...
answer: Yeah. That was it. You know, I can do this. You should really go try on the dress for my mom.

question: I was going to go for a run first, it's been three days since I got out, I'm feeling crazy.
answer: Whatever. Margaret isn't accustomed to Richard talking to her this way, but doesn't push it.

question: What now? Margaret follows the smoke, and hears a mysterious DRUMBEAT. She soon discovers a tremendous bonfire by the water, and a SHAMAN dancing around it. He is dressed in a loin cloth, and wears a carved bear's head mask and tribal make up. His belly shakes as he spastically moves around the fire. The Shaman sings a song that sounds centuries old. What, ah, are you doing?
answer: My shaman Kevin told me to get out here and clear my head. As you know, things have been a little crazy around here. You should join me.

question: Ya know, I've got to get back.
answer: You closed minded southerners amuse me. Never willing to leave the nest and try

question: I'm a big fan of the nest. Geoffrey throws sand into the fire and it blazes higher.
answer: Dance with me! You besmirch my ways if you deny my circle. Worried she's going to really piss him off, Margaret relents.

question: OK, OK. I "accept your circle." Geoffrey smiles and throws more sand into the fire.
answer: Clear your mind and follow me. Geoffrey begins dancing slowly, contorting his body. Margaret follows, always a half step behind, and can't get into it. After a few moments, Margaret stops.

question: I'm gonna head back.
answer: We're not done.

question: I think I am. Margaret begins to leave. Geoffrey calls after her.
answer: Margaret? Margaret stops and turns around. GEOFFREY I'm sorry we got off on the wrong foot. But I'm making an effort here. Don't leave now. Much to her chagrin, Margaret stays. Geoffrey is pleased. GEOFFREY Thank you. Yai...takuju magaluam Ut uksu lingm ik pifiksailiriju m 1k... Geoffrey throws more sand on the fire to make it go higher and speeds up the dance. Margaret is getting better, but it is still painfully awkward.

question: Me what?
answer: Chant.

question: Chant what?
answer: Whatever comes out, just chant. It is the way. You'll feel better.

question: I can't...
answer: Close your eyes. Chant. Margaret and Geoffrey keep dancing. Margaret closes her eyes, but can't figure out what to say. GEOFFREY Chant!

question: I don't know any chants!
answer: Chant! Chant! The drum beat continues.

question: He does this to keep in touch with "his people".
answer: Don't make fun of my heritage! And it was helping. Don't you feel better? I feel better.

question: Come on sweetie, we need to get you cleaned up. You've got a dress to try on. And Geoffrey, put that fire out and come in and help us with this wedding. Geoffrey turns off the boom box that was hidden in the trees and the drum beat stops.
answer: Fine. With a fire extinguisher, the bonfire comes to an end.

question: You go work downstairs, I'll finish this. Debbie tries to calm down, but can't. GRANDMA ANNIE Go! Debbie nods in agreement. Smiling from ear to ear, she leaves in tears. Margaret and Annie watch her go. GRANDMA ANNIE Had to get rid of her before I gave you this. Don't think she woulda recovered. Grandma Annie comes from behind and puts her arms around Margaret's neck. When she is done, a stunning blue necklace lays on Margaret's neck. GRANDMA ANNIE You needed something blue. It's silly, but I didn't want to take any chances.
answer: It's beautiful.

question: It's hematite. Alaska diamonds. The blue ones like this are very rare. My great grandfather gave it to my great grandmother when they were married. They were quite a scandal, you know. He was Russian and she was Tlingit.
answer: How'd they stay together?

question: Don't know. But I'm sure happy they did, none of us would be here if they hadn't. Grandma and Margaret admire the necklace in the mirror. GRANDMA ANNIE I want you to have it. This is awful news for Margaret. She might as well be stealing from Annie.
answer: No, no, no. I can't. Really.

question: I don't want to hear it. It's yours. Grandmothers like to give their stuff away to their grandchildren. Makes us feel like we'll always be a part of your life, even after we're gone. Take it. Margaret puts her hand to the necklace, and for the first time feels like a complete and total fraud. GRANDMA ANNIE Are you feeling all right, dear? Margaret doesn't speak. Annie patiently waits for her reply.
answer: Well. Thing is... Margaret deliberates spilling her guts to Annie, but can't. MARGARET ...the dress is just a little tight.

question: We need to talk.
answer: I'm a little busy.

question: Well I'm freaking out. I need to get away from here. From everyone. Now.
answer: Go for another run.

question: No! I did that. It did not help.
answer: I'm a little tired of you making demands and me just jumping...

question: We're not going to need any of this if I don't get out of here.
answer: OK, high maintenance. Let's go.

question: Move over, I'm driving. Margaret cuts in front of Richard and grabs the wheel.
answer: You don't know where we're going. Margaret opens up the throttle and they are off.

question: It doesn't matter.
answer: The north pole. Congratulations, we made it. It's a glacier. Tracy's Arm. You better let me take it from here.

question: I'm fine.
answer: Oh. OK. So like me, you've navigated a lot of glacier fields? And not died? Margaret reluctantly moves aside and lets Richard steer. RICHARD Lady, you've got issues.

question: Yeah. I'm a control freak. Fine.
answer: It doesn't stop there.

question: This coming from the sociopath.
answer: Oh, please.

question: I'd never bring me here.
answer: You drove!

question: I mean to Alaska.
answer: Are you kidding me? Richard pulls next to the glacier and turns off the engine.

question: You're sick. Doing this to them.
answer: I explained to you...

question: They love you. Do you get that?
answer: Of course.

question: And you're still willing to lie to them?
answer: Like you didn't know.

question: Didn't know what?
answer: That we were going to lie to them.

question: I didn't know!
answer: Well that makes you either stupid, or ignorant.

question: You think I'm stupid?
answer: No, but what's behind door number two... Forgot what?

question: What it was like!
answer: What what was like?

question: To have a family! I forgot what it was like to have a family. I've been on my own since I was thirteen, and I'd forgot what it was like to have people that love you, and make you breakfast, and give you necklaces...
answer: We need to head back...

question: Alone. I need alone time.
answer: What? Margaret looks at Richard with a scared and confused look.

question: I'm, uh, about to lose my shit. Big time. I need a second.
answer: But... Margaret!

question: No talking!
answer: Watch your step, OK? It can be dangerous.

question: Again, you're not supposed to be... Margaret doesn't finish her sentence.
answer: Margaret? Richard turns around and looks for Margaret. He doesn't see her. He gets out of the boat and goes onto the glacier, walking in the direction he last saw Margaret. RICHARD Margaret? I know I'm breaking "the rules" here, but where are you? He takes one more step before he hears... I'm sorry. I'm sorry. Just relax. I'll get you out of there. You've broken through an ice bridge. It happens all the time. No biggie.

question: Don't do that.
answer: Don't do what?

question: The thing that doctors do in E.R. when they tell the gunshot victim who is bleeding to death that they're going to be OK. Don't do that!
answer: It's not like that. Really. We do need to be careful here though, I don't want us both to fall in. Stay still, OK?

question: Uh-huh. Richard is ten feet away from Margaret now. He's checking the ice to see if it is stable. He slowly walks her way.
answer: So, I'm going to walk up to you and very slowly pull you out. OK?

question: I'm really cold.
answer: Yeah, that's normal when you're surrounded by ice. So I'm going to pull you up by your armpits. I'm probably going to touch boob. But don't freak out. Margaret shakes her head yes. Richard reaches down and slowly lifts her out of the ice. Margaret doesn't say a word. RICHARD When I get you all the way out, I need you to hold onto me. I'm going to carry you over there. Margaret nods yes as she puts her arms around Richard. He's strong, so it isn't difficult for him to slowly carry her "over the threshold" style, away from the hole in the ice. He speaks once they're safe.

question: You said it was "no biggie".
answer: Yeah. Well. You OK?

question: Yeah. I'm fine. Richard smiles. Margaret smiles back. Richard walks very comfortably with her in his arms. She fits just right. Margaret looks up to Richard gratefully. MARGARET
answer: You woulda laughed at me.

question: Yeah. While I was getting my camera. The two stare at each other for a beat. There's a real spark. They might kiss.
answer: Gertrude wants me back. Whoah. Not what she was expecting. She looks down.

question: And?
answer: Well. It seemed like you were having... second thoughts.

question: Yeah. I was.
answer: Maybe we should do it. Come clean.

question: Put me down. Richard puts Margaret down near the boat. She tries to regain her composure. MARGARET You wanna call it off?
answer: If you do.

question: Come on, we gotta get ready. Margaret and Richard storm out of the squash court. What was I thinking? They act like they're nice, but really, they're evil.
answer: He's only doing it because he loves you.

question: Are you defending him? Are you defending the king dick?
answer: Just stop. Think about this.

question: Oh, you bet. They make it to the Gazebo, where Ramone awaits. MARGARET Ramone. No.
answer: Then why is your hand up?

question: I have something to say. It's not a question though.
answer: Can it wait til after?

question: Uh. Um. No.
answer: What are you doing? Margaret gathers herself and turns around to the crowd. They stare back, unsure what to make of this foreigner.

question: Hey there, folks. Thanks for coming out. I've got a little announcement to make about the "wedding."
answer: Don't do this. Margaret smiles and squeezes Richard's hand.

question: Not sure the best way to tell you all this. But, uh... I made Richard marry me. This is all a sham. Gilbertson victoriously pumps his fist in the air.
answer: Now wait...

question: Uh-huh. Yeah. That's great Frank. Good news. Talk to you on Monday. Margaret hangs up.
answer: So Frank's back in? Margaret nods distractedly. Getting Frank to do the publicity tour doesn't mean much right now.

question: Yup. He's in. For now.
answer: Maybe this'll be your Mockingbird?

question: Yeah. Right. Margaret starts collecting her bags.
answer: Great exit back there.

question: Thanks. Fun weekend.
answer: Same old, same old, around here.

question: Wasn't sure if your mom would want me to strip the sheets, so I just left them.
answer: I'll let her know.

question: It was getting too messy. We weren't going to be able to keep it up.
answer: Don't start lying to me now. Margaret stops for a moment.

question: I heard you and Gertrude at the school. I think she meant what she said. She's a great girl, you should stay. It's the right thing. You're perfect for each other.
answer: But... but what about you? What are you gonna do? Margaret wants to keep the conversation short.

question: Don't worry about me. I'll survive.
answer: So what? This is it?

question: I want you to say the words.
answer: I'm not doing great in the dignity department, can we not do this right now?

question: Say it. Margaret closes her eyes. Hating that it's come to this.
answer: I'll publish your book. Gilbertson smiles.

question: So here's the deal. I'm going to have a million questions for you tomorrow... Gertrude sits down next to Richard.
answer: Thanks. Richard thanks her with a kiss on the cheek. Then, realizing where and who he is with, he puts his beer down. He turns to Gertrude again with a determined look, gives her a kiss on the lips, then follows it up with an even bigger kiss. When they finish, Gertrude is grinning, eyes closed. Richard looks worried. Something is wrong.

question: You have been practicing.
answer: Waddya mean?

question: Well. Margaret told me that you, uh, turned into bit of a man whore down there. Richard looks down. A bit ashamed. Gertrude makes light. GERTRUDE You're gonna have to put that in check if you move back. Cause me and Beth Cable are the only two real options up here... and I'll kick that bitch's ass. Richard gives her a polite smile. He's not really in the mood to joke. Gertrude notices. GERTRUDE So no jokes yet? Too soon?
answer: I'm sorry. I'm just a little... confused.

question: That kiss didn't seem "confused." Richard takes a beat to collect himself.
answer: You're amazing, Gert. And I've thought about being with you for a long time. A long time. When you said those things at the school? I've dreamed about hearing you say those things.

question: I don't know.
answer: I think I have to find out.

question: Find out what?
answer: If she feels the same way. Gertrude begins to tear up, but won't let herself cry.

question: Well. OK then. What's a girl gonna do? I guess you want who you want. Gertrude gives a melancholy smile.
answer: I'm so sorry.

question: Uh-huh. Richard gets up.
answer: Are you OK?

question: She violated you. We should report her.
answer: Who you gonna report her to, mom?

question: Oh my God. He's got the Stockholm syndrome.
answer: I don't have the Stockholm syndrome. And she didn't violate me.

question: What is going on, Richard? Richard slows down and explains to his mom.
answer: I'm sorry I lied to you. That was an awful thing to do. But it took this weekend for me to see how funny, and screwed up and perfect Margaret is for me. I think she's... the one.

question: But you already thought she was the one.
answer: No, I didn't. Not until she left.

question: Really? Does she think that too?
answer: I don't know. I've got to get to the airport to find out. Debbie doesn't say anything, then breaks into a smile.

question: He's going to stop her from leaving! At the airport!
answer: But I gotta hurry. Her plane leaves any second. I might not make it.

question: I don't have time to explain this to you.
answer: Well then make some god-damn time. Cause I won't let you throw your life away for some woman.

question: I don't care.
answer: Excuse me?

question: I don't care. I love you and want you to understand. But I'm not asking your permission here. I'm doing this.
answer: Oh, really? From behind them, Annie stands up and shouts.

question: Flight 1601, you're clear for takeoff. Tower. Talk to me.
answer: Hey Chuck, it's Richard.

question: Hey man. Heard about your lady bailing. How often does this happen to you?
answer: Need you to do me a solid, brother. I gotta see my girl and she's on that flight. Could you stop it for me?

question: No can do brohan. Need a good reason for the FAA holes. Lose my jobby job if I delivered that favor.
answer: Oh, c'mon Chuck!

question: Oh, good lord. What the hell are you doing? Everyone in the tower smiles. They're making progress.
answer: We need to talk.

question: About what?
answer: Have you ever thought there might be a reason we've been together for the last three years?

question: As boss and assistant.
answer: Things change, Margaret. Yeah, things change.

question: Is that the best you got? Geoffrey hits Richard, as if to say "see, that's what I said." Richard composes himself.
answer: Now, tell me the truth. When you left, were you relieved or sad that we didn't have an excuse to be together anymore? Geoffrey gives Richard the thumbs up. That was a good one.

question: What's your point?
answer: Because I am sick that you left. And if you feel sick too, then why shouldn't we just be together? Margaret goes to answer, but stops. Richard is right. She wants to go back. Even the passengers on the plane can see it. Gilbertson panics.

question: Are you thinking about going back to him? Margaret doesn't answer. MR. GILBERTSON We have a deal! You can't back out now! The flight attendant steps in, annoyed that Gilbertson is trying to break up Richard and Margaret.
answer: Sir, you need to sit down.

question: I will do no such thing.
answer: Sir, I'm ordering you to return to your seat. Other passengers yell "sit down asshole" at Gilbertson.

question: Who said that?
answer: Sir, this is your third and final warning!
